abstract.p: Book Review editors introduce John Horgan review of Chris Mooney book The Republican War on Science (S)

block.p: During the 2004 presidential campaign, more than 7,000 scientists, including at least 20 Nobel laureates, signed a petition organized by the Union of Concerned Scientists, an advocacy group based in Cambridge, Mass., charging the Bush administration with distorting scientific information to advance its political agenda. Meanwhile, a political action group called Scientists and Engineers for Change spoke out against President Bush at events in Ohio, Pennsylvania and other swing states.

During the 2004 presidential campaign, more than 7,000 scientists, including at least 20 Nobel laureates, signed a petition organized by the Union of Concerned Scientists, an advocacy group based in Cambridge, Mass., charging the Bush administration with distorting scientific information to advance its political agenda. Meanwhile, a political action group called Scientists and Engineers for Change spoke out against President Bush at events in Ohio, Pennsylvania and other swing states.

Just what is going on here? This week, the veteran science journalist John Horgan reviews Chris Mooney's ''Republican War on Science,'' a book he calls a ''diatribe'' marred by ''preaching-to-the-choir self-righteousness'' -- but one that gets a vitally important story basically right. ''Scientists can at times act like just another special interest group, trying to get a bigger slice of the federal pie,'' Horgan said in an e-mail message. ''And they are too quick to peg you as an 'anti-science' religious nut if you oppose, say, funding for stem-cell research.'' Still, he insists, the claim that the administration has manipulated scientific information on issues ranging from climate change to abortion to missile defense isn't just the fevered fantasy of Bush-hating polemicists. ''The actions of the administration have been so egregious that I believe scientists are justified in calling it 'anti-science,' '' he said, adding, ''Uh-oh, I'm letting my bias show.'' Horgan's review begins on Page 11.
